title: Mr. Johnson: Inguinal Hernia Impacting Core Stability and Daily Living
clinical_history: Mr. Daniel Johnson is a 48-year-old warehouse manager who reports a progressive bulge in his right lower abdomen for the past 3 months. He noticed mild discomfort after lifting a heavy box at work but had no sudden, sharp pain. Over the last 4 weeks, he has experienced intermittent aching localized to the right inguinal region, exacerbated by physical exertion, coughing, or prolonged standing. His pain subsides at rest or when lying supine. On examination, a palpable, reducible mass is noted in the right inguinal region, which becomes prominent with Valsalva maneuver. He denies any nausea, vomiting, or systemic symptoms.

nprs.affected_area: Secondary discomfort radiating to right groin with heavy lifting

aggrevating_factors: Heavy lifting, bending, coughing, sustained standing, straining during bowel movements.
picture: Pain and palpable bulge are most evident in the right inguinal region, especially during activity; patient often supports the right lower abdomen with his hand when rising from a chair or when lifting.
easing_factors: Rest, lying supine, use of an abdominal binder, avoidance of heavy lifting.
past_history: No previous surgeries; reports occasional constipation; no prior episodes of abdominal or groin pain.
medical_history: Hypertension managed with lisinopril; BMI: 31 (obese); no diabetes or anticoagulant use.
medications: Lisinopril 10mg daily; acetaminophen as needed for pain (rarely used).
personal_history: Non-smoker, moderate alcohol use socially; engaged in regular manual work; reports increased work demands over the last year and limited time for exercise.
imaging: Abdominal ultrasound confirmed a reducible right inguinal hernia with no evidence of bowel incarceration.
